intro: Thyridia, commonly known as the common bladderwort, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. These plants are characterized by their small, bladder-like structures called vesicles, which are used to trap small aquatic organisms. Thyridia species are typically found in freshwater habitats such as ponds, ditches, and slow-moving streams. They are carnivorous plants, relying on the captured prey for nutrients due to the poor nutrient content of their aquatic environment. Their unique morphology and ecological role make them an interesting subject in botanical studies.
